topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: PHP Hello World Sample

body.p: This very simple PHP web app displays the text "Hello World!". This is a demonstration of the minimum requirements to build a functional application. Use this sample to ensure that you have set up your environment for deployment to Helion Development Platform.

ul.li: An installation of the HPE Helion Development Platform.
Access to an Application Lifecycle Service (ALS) Cluster
Access to the Helion command-line client (CLI).
Access to the web-based ALS Management Console.
Register for access to the HPE Helion Development Platform (HDN).

p.xref: Click here to access the code repository.

section.p: Manifest.yml is a configuration file used to specify settings. For PHP only the name and buildpack fields are required. The buildpack field is a URL for the buildpack that supports the necessary language and/or framework.
This app uses the Cloud Foundry PHP buildpack. For more technical details about buildpacks and the composer.json file, please see the README included in the download package.

section.title: Deploy the Application
section.p: Note: Application Lifecycle Service clusters that require an upstream HTTP proxy to access the internet will need to be made aware of the proxy. The sample applications require access to the Internet in order to download dependent packages.
Use the Helion client to deploy your app to Helion Development Platform.

ol.li: Open the ALS Management Console. The Management Console is the web-based administrative interface that can be reached by typing the ALS endpoint URL into a browser window.

If the file push was successful, you should see hello-world-php in the list of available applications. Note that the name, along with other variable values, was supplied through the manifest.yml file.

Click View App to see your app in action.
This application displays a text message: Hello World!

section.title: Key Code Snippets
section.p: This simple PHP script prints "Hello World".

The manifest.yml file is the configuration information used by ALS to set up the environment. The buildpack element here informs ALS on the correct buildpack to use for PHP which ensures the correct tools and runtimes are installed in the application environment.

section.title: Key Learnings

ol.li: ALS requires configuration information to create an environment for your app, including buildpack information for PHP. Configuration information is contained in the manifest.yml file.
You interact with and deploy your app using the ALS command line client or the web-based ALS Management Console.
